120A.title: Twentieth-Century Literature
120A.description: The modern novel, the avant-garde, cubist poetry, Dada and Surrealism, the theatre before the Second World War.

162A.title: Perspectives on History
162A.description: This course will study both contemporary and subsequent reactions to historic events or figures. Topics vary from year to year.

121B.title: Literary Themes, Genres, and Structures
121B.description: Topics vary from year to year. Past topics have included "litterature fantastique," science fiction, autobiography, French lyric poetry.

301.title: Teaching French in College: First Year
301.description: Bi-weekly lectures on methodology, grading and testing, demonstration class with required attendance five times per week; language laboratory observations; supervised classroom practice. Additional seminars and discussion sections on methodology. Required for all Graduate Student Instructors teaching French 1 for the first time.

176.title: Introduction to French Linguistics
176.description: An introduction to the major branches of linguistic analysis (phonology, morphology--including word-formation-syntax, and semantics) as applied to the French language.

230A.title: Studies in 17th-Century Literature
230A.description: Offerings vary from year to year. See the Department's Course Description for current topic.

13.title: Intermediate Conversation
13.description: Intermediate French conversation. May not be repeated for credit.

13.title: Intermediate Conversation
13.description: Intermediate French conversation. May not be repeated for credit.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research for Advanced Undergraduates
199.description: Enrollment restricted according to College regulations. Individual instruction only in areas not covered by courses.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research for Advanced Undergraduates
199.description: Enrollment restricted according to College regulations. Individual instruction only in areas not covered by courses.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research for Advanced Undergraduates
199.description: Enrollment restricted according to College regulations. Individual instruction only in areas not covered by courses.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research for Advanced Undergraduates
199.description: Enrollment restricted according to College regulations. Individual instruction only in areas not covered by courses.

201.title: History of the French Language
201.description: A history of the French language from its Latin origins through the modern period. Emphasis on "external history" (development of the language in relation to other social and cultural phenomena) with some historical grammar (phonology, morphology, syntax, orthography) introduced through textual readings from the various historical periods. Sociolinguistic emphasis, focusing on the emergence of a standard language and its relationship to other varieties of French.

142AC.title: The Cultures of Franco-America
142AC.description: Literary and cultural texts that emerge out of the long history of the French in North America and of Americans in France. Topics may vary from semester to semester, but the course will always take substantial account of the experiences and histories of representations of different ethnic groups. Students should consult the department's course bulletin well before the beginning of the semester for details.

117B.title: Seventeenth-Century Literature
117B.description: The concept of classicism and the development of tragedy. Jansenism, the doctrine of Port-Royal. Social satire and comedy.

180C.title: French Civilization
180C.description: Survey of French civilization: history, arts, and society, through the interpretation of literary texts. 180A: The Middle Ages; 180B: The Ancien Regime; 180C: The 19th Century; 180D: The 20th Century.

2.title: Elementary French
2.description: Introduction to speaking, listening, reading, and writing in French. Continuation of French 1.

3.title: Intermediate French
3.description: Building on foundation established in first year, trains students in listening, reading, writing, and speaking French. Review and refinement of grammar.

43B.title: Aspects of French Culture
43B.description: Various historical and aesthetic themes and problems in the development of French civilization. In English.

146A.title: Introduction to French Linguistics
146A.description: An introduction to the major branches of linguistic analysis (phonology, morphology--including word formation--syntax, and semantics) as applied to the French language.

251.title: Francophone Literature
251.description: Focuses upon the relationship between oral and written cultures in Francophone Africa and/or the Caribbean: lyric and narrative poetry, drama and novels; the presence of oral tradition in written forms, narrative techniques borrowed from storytelling tradition, the definition of traditional metaphors and imagery; idealization of lost worlds; the conflict of traditional culture and modernism; the search for political identity and independence.

200.title: Proseminar
200.description: This course is designed to give all new graduate students a broad view of the department's faculty, the courses they teach, and their fields of research. In addition, it will introduce students to some practical aspects of the graduate career, issues that pertain to specific fields of research, and questions currently being debated across the profession.

102.title: Reading and Writing Skills in French
102.description: An exploration of the ways words and images structure thought, communication and interactions of the subject and society. Development of reading and writing skills leading to correct and effective expression in French.

102.title: Reading and Writing Skills in French
102.description: An exploration of the ways words and images structure thought, communication and interactions of the subject and society. Development of reading and writing skills leading to correct and effective expression in French.

24.title: Freshman Seminars
24.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester. Enrollment limited to freshmen.

265A.title: Modern Studies
265A.description: Offerings vary from year to year. See the department's course description for current topic.

103A.title: Language and Culture
103A.description: Discussion and composition based on the analysis of literary and cultural texts.

14.title: Advanced Conversation
14.description: Advanced French conversation. This course may not be repeated for credit.

4.title: Advanced Intermediate French
4.description: Advanced training in listening, reading, writing, and speaking French. Review and refinement of grammar.
